fields.preview_text: “Dear Kat, Finals are coming up. I’m stressed, unprepared, and starting to panic. I might survive by sheer force of will and excessive amounts of caffeine, but is there another way? How will I get through this?”
fields.content_html:
“Dear Kat, Finals are coming up. I’m stressed, unprepared, and starting to panic. I might survive by sheer force of will and excessive amounts of caffeine, but is there another way? How will I get through this?”

Dear Reader,

There might be another way, but I don’t know one! If you do, please call me at (678) 999-8212.

Let’s take a deep breath because more stress means higher cortisol levels, which means worse focus and sleep. Remember: You have been learning throughout this entire semester, not just since you started outlining (or whenever you will start). Instead of making a study plan purely based on maximizing content consumption, consider how you best retain info. I also suggest minimizing daily choices you have to make, like what to eat or where to study. It may not do much, but having less decision fatigue generally may help you be consistent and stick to a schedule.

You may feel like you can’t do practice tests until your outline is done or you have reviewed everything. This won’t resonate with everyone, but if it resonates with you, ignore that feeling! It is likely just a manifestation of procrastination (mmm that rolls off the tongue). Practice exams are terrifying and it is easy to logic yourself out of them. Just do them. You don’t need to replicate an exam setting perfectly or do an entire exam in one sitting. All I can say is that knowing the material doesn’t matter (exam-wise) if you aren’t comfortable putting it in writing. Also, test out Exam4 before your exams because it is not user friendly!

It will be over before you know it. It’s been lovely advising you this semester. Keep the questions flowing and go see Gladiator II (this is not a paid ad).

Best,
Kat

Katerina Kakkis is a 3L and a Contributor for The Verdict.

fields.title: The Five Most Romantic 1L Cases
fields.preview_text: Valentine’s Day is the libertarian’s holiday. The government usually has an interest in regulating things as unfair and dangerous as romance, but in love we are free—heartbroken, mogged on, gaslit, bankrupted, ghosted, and embarrassed, but free. Here are the five most romantic 1L cases.
fields.content_html:
Valentine’s Day is the libertarian’s holiday.1 The government usually has an interest in regulating things as unfair and dangerous as romance, but in love we are free—heartbroken, mogged on, gaslit, bankrupted, ghosted, and embarrassed, but free. Lovers are free to remain childless, free to marry who they love, free to avoid tort creditors, and free to do whatever is going on in Michael H. Here are the five most romantic 1L cases.

B-tier

In re Estate of Kievernagel, 83 Cal. Rptr. 3d 311 (2008)

“No ma’am, your late husband made it clear he wanted his sperm destroyed,” is how one attack outline describes this case. Iris Kievernagel could not convince her husband Joseph to have children in life or in death. While I feel bad for Iris, this B-tier romance does create some puzzles for us budding legal eagles. Why does the court accept Joseph’s consent form and destroy his potential progeny, but reject the will in Eyerman (holding due to “public policy”2 you can’t destroy a deceased woman’s house despite her really wanting it destroyed upon her death)? Was Joseph’s sperm intellectual property? Will the president, the self-proclaimed “father of IVF,”3 issue an executive order clarifying these issues?

Michael H. v. Gerald D., 491 U.S. 110 (1989)

Michael has a baby with Carole, a model who lives next door. Unfortunately, Carole is married to Gerald, a French oil executive. Gerald’s name ends up on the baby’s birth certificate, and the couple won’t let Michael have a relationship with his biological child.

So Michael stands on the 14th amendment substantive due process tradition to assert a right to see his out-of-wedlock child. But the Court decides it’s super constitutional for California to prioritize Carole’s marriage with Gerald over Michael’s relationship with his child.4 S-tier drama, B-tier romance.

A-tier

Obergefell v. Hodges, 576 U.S. 644 (2015)

I’m pretty sure Jim Obergefell liked his husband John more than vice versa when they met in 1992: “John liked to say for us, ‘It wasn’t love at first sight, it was love at third sight.’”5 John liked to say for us.

John Arthur was a confident, mister-steal-your-man type. Jim was diffident and still in the closet. But the second time they met, perhaps scared of being “condemned to live in loneliness,”6 Jim found the courage to solicit a date from John. And the third time they met, I guess John finally saw in Jim what Jim was seeing in John, and the rest is history. Obergefell broke ground for timid, low-charisma men everywhere.

Loving v. Virginia, 388 U.S. 1 (1967)

Hank Williams Jr.’s song “If Heaven Ain’t a Lot Like Dixie” is basically all my values and preferences inverted (“Take me to hell or New York City/It would be about the same to me”).7 But I unironically love that track since it’s cool when people are proud of where they’re from.

Mildred and Richard Loving grew up in Virginia, but they fled to Washington D.C. after police burst into their bedroom to enforce anti-miscegenation laws. D.C. was not for them: “[T]he Lovings missed family, friends and their easy country lifestyle in the rolling Virginia hills.”8 So inspired by the Civil Rights Movement, they went back home and got the Court to legalize their marriage. Very moving power couple: A-tier.

S-tier

Sawada v. Endo, 561 P.2d 1291 (1977)

But it’s 2025, wokeness is over, merit is back, and those DEI cases sure won’t be breaking into the S-tier.

Kokichi Endo injures a couple, the Sawadas, in a car accident, and it’s totally his fault. But when the Sawadas come after him for damages, Endo shields his property with the old “that’s not my stuff, that’s my marriage’s stuff, and wait my marriage just gave it to our son so you can’t touch it, ha!” trick.

Love conquers all, including creditors.

Daniel Bugingo is a 2L and a Writer for The Verdict.

1 Scott Alexander, Love and Liberty, Astral Codex Ten (Feb. 14, 2024), www.astralcodexten.com/p/love-and-liberty.

2 If “because of public policy” means something more to you than “because I said so” please email me. I’m more than halfway through law school, it’s been explained to me several times, and it still strikes me as insanely Calvinball, even for law.

3 Gram Slattery, Donald Trump Calls Himself ‘Father of IVF’ at All-Women Town Hall, Reuters (Oct. 16, 2024), www.reuters.com/world/us/donald-trump-calls-himself-father-ivf-all-women-town-hall-2024-10-16.

4 “Where, however, the child is born into an extant marital family, the natural father’s unique opportunity conflicts with the similarly unique opportunity of the husband of the marriage; and it is not unconstitutional for the State to give categorical preference to the latter.” Michael H. v. Gerald D., 491 U.S. at 129.

5 Tess Bonn, Jim Obergefell Looks Back on 8 Years of Marriage Equality—And the Great Love That Made It Possible, Katie Couric Media (June 26, 2023), www.katiecouric.com/news/jim-obergefell-interview-marriage-equality.

6 Obergefell v. Hodges, 576 U.S. at 681.

7 Hank Williams, Jr., If Heaven Ain’t a Lot Like Dixie (1982).

8 Douglas Martin, Mildred Loving, Who Battled Ban on Mixed-Race Marriage, Dies at 68, N.Y. Times (May 6, 2008), nytimes.com/2008/05/06/us/06loving.html.

fields.title: On Jonathan Berry's “Beyond DEI: Rescuing the Human Person from Inhuman Law”
fields.preview_text: "Jonathan Berry's talk purported to tackle what he deemed a pressing issue in modern legal governance: the rising influence of large, anti-majoritarian corporations. In actuality, the talk used flimsy arguments about the commodification of identity to justify dissolving DEI initiatives. Berry's speech is reflective of the larger conservative push to scapegoat minorities as responsible for social issues, falling squarely in line with the fascist politics of President Donald Trump."
fields.content_html:
On November 18, 2024, Columbia Law School’s Federalist Society hosted a lecture by Jonathan Berry, best known for co-authoring Project 2025. His talk, titled “Beyond DEI: Rescuing the Human Person from Inhuman Law,” purported to tackle what he deemed a pressing issue in modern legal governance: the rising influence of large, anti-majoritarian corporations. In actuality, the talk used flimsy arguments about the commodification of identity to justify dissolving DEI initiatives. Berry’s speech is reflective of the larger conservative push to scapegoat minorities as responsible for social issues, falling squarely in line with the fascist politics of President Donald Trump.

According to Berry, corporate commodification has two damaging implications. First, because high-ranking corporate officials skew left politically, liberal ideologies have an undue influence on policy. Second, large companies commodify identity and culture by selling the idea of “limitlessness” to brand products. As he described it, limitlessness encourages people to seek opportunities beyond their capabilities, presuming that their identity will compensate for their lack of qualifications.

Berry forwarded various solutions to the issue—from prohibiting companies from enacting DEI quotas through government regulation to beginning board meetings with the Pledge of Allegiance—that echoed policies proposed in his “Mandate for Leadership.” His advice to lecturees was to reject limitlessness and instead to recognize the constraints on their potential. In practice, this looks like only applying for summer positions that one believes she is actually qualified for rather than applying broadly.

On its face, Berry’s message of accepting one’s limits doesn’t seem problematic. The lecture began to unravel when Berry applied this argument to minority groups. Berry’s example of the commodification of Black identity was a bus advertisement that read “Wakanda Forever.” When prompted to explain the connection between “Wakanda Forever” and limitlessness, Berry simply repeated his earlier assertion without justifying how the advertisement targeted or commodified Black identity. Seemingly, Berry made the assumption that an advertising campaign for the most widely-watched media franchise aimed to promote false courage in Black people, solely because it featured a majority-Black cast.

To Berry’s credit, there is merit to his claim about the commodification of identity by large corporations. LGBT+ advocates have long critiqued “corporate pride” for exploiting the queer community for profit rather than meaningfully supporting queer rights. Where Berry errs is his assertion that this trend is unique to minority groups like queer and Black people, when in fact nearly every holiday is commodified. Pharmacies stock up on cards and flowers for Mother’s Day, department stores sell deer ears and stockings near Christmas, and Peeps make their annual appearance every Easter. Is CVS Pharmacy trying to sell the idea that motherhood has no constraints? Or, the more likely answer: Corporations capitalize on trends because they want to make money. Berry’s argument has little to do with liberal corporations forcing identity politics down America’s throat, and much more to do with them trying to maximize profits.

It may seem like Berry’s claims are simply misled, but analyzing the framing of the lecture reveals something more insidious. Although Berry spends most of his time critiquing large corporations generally, he chose to title his speech “Beyond DEI,” centering a particularly inflammatory, yet underdeveloped, theme of his talk. He cherry-picked examples of corporate commodification that focused on minority groups while glossing over ways in which every identity is commodified. For every Black Panther that chants “Wakanda Forever,” there are five Interstellars that say “Our destiny lies above us.” Berry’s choice to highlight minorities shows more of a commitment to dissolving DEI initiatives than critiquing corporate commodification. Why wouldn’t starting board meetings with the Pledge of Allegiance lead to the commodification of “American” identity? Why are “DEI hires” examples of corporate limitlessness, but nepotism hires are not? These glaring contradictions aren’t an issue to Berry. The only laws he views as “inhuman” are those that aim to benefit historically marginalized groups.

Berry’s speech is indicative of the modern conservative political strategy: Create a bogeyman and garner support from fear. While the myth of all-powerful woke corporations drives his argument, he provides little convincing evidence that DEI initiatives are uniquely harmful. Instead, he relies on buzzwords to inflame a non-issue, a tactic that has proven successful for many conservative thinkers. Most prominent among these is President Donald Trump, whose campaign boiled down to a politics of blame. Trump galvanized his base by targeting groups that posed some manufactured threat to civil society. Your neighborhoods are crime-riddled because of Mexicans illegally crossing the border. Your kids are unsafe because the liberals are doing transgender operations in grade school. Not even your pets are secure; Haitians in Springfield are eating the dogs and eating the cats. Where Trump and Berry align is the assertion of life-altering problems absent evidence of their existence or severity. Anyone with Google and basic discernment skills would realize that all of Trump’s threats are baseless. The success of Trump’s campaign revealed that empirics-based argument is much less effective than fear-mongering.

Although Trump and Berry’s weaponization of lies seems novel to those versed in modern American politics, there are clear analogies between this political strategy and the strategies of authoritarian rulers. In a 2024 article for the New Yorker, historian Timothy Snyder compared Trump’s disavowal of facts to the political strategies of fascist leaders like Putin, Mussolini, and Hitler. Everything that Trump says is the truth, and everyone that disagrees is the true fascist. This is particularly alarming when the “truth” justifies harming politically-vulnerable groups. Berry’s speech should not be viewed as a fringe conservative viewpoint, but an integral part of Trump-era fascism.

As law students, we have an obligation to fight back against dangerous narratives and hold speakers accountable for unfounded claims. Instead of prima facie dismissing beliefs like Berry’s as ridiculous, we have to critically engage with them to point out their contradictions and holes in logic. Only by remaining vigilant in our critical thinking can we resist a political schema seemingly adamant to crush it.

Elijah Pitt is a 1L and a Writer for the Verdict.

fields.title: Advisory Opinion: Should I Ask My Crush Out?
fields.content_html:
It is that loved-up time of the year and you’re asking yourself if you should make a move with that special someone. This fun and flirty flowchart is here to help you! Happy Valentine’s Day.

Disclaimer: A gentle reminder that I am not a romance expert (shocking, but true) and this is not professional (or even credible) advice. Please consult your friends or Esther Perel before proceeding with any crush-related activity. Also, I love, love and am so happy for all the law school couples and flings.

Katerina Kakkis is a 3L and a Contributor for The Verdict.

fields.title: Cross Examination
How to MPRE
fields.content_html:
The Multistate Professional Responsibility Examination approaches. If you’re a 3L who hasn’t taken it and isn’t planning to practice in Wisconsin or Puerto Rico, you’re likely taking it in at the end of the month. How do you study?

The MPRE is not a difficult exam. Failing it is an “unforced error”: as long as you spend a minimum amount of time studying, you’ll meet your jurisdiction’s threshold (85 in New York, 86 in California, a surprisingly low 75 in D.C.: check your jurisdiction here). So don’t just walk in. You don’t want to be studying for the August exam instead of sipping Mai Tais on the white sands of Tahiti.

I liked the BARBRI videos. No, I am not a paid actor—I wouldn’t be in law school if I were, and besides, the videos are free. Dr. Paul Lisnek—great guy, loves dogs—will entertain, educate, and even encourage a rethink of the fashion value of a bow tie. Watch the videos, do the questions, and take a practice exam under exam conditions. (The Themis practice tests are harder, so try those if you’re feeling smart.) If you’re scoring below 100, review your shakier areas. The summary study guides are helpful for the most common topics. And don’t overstudy. There’s no award for highest MPRE score, and you have better things to do. Shoot for 100 and you’ll be golden.

Some people use the “Jesus Minus One” strategy to answer questions. Basically, “what would the most virtuous person do—if they also wanted to turn a profit.” I don’t like this thinking. While there are patterns, ultimately whether something is ethical under the Model Rules is a case-by-case analysis. For example, many conflicts of interest are imputed to the rest of your firm, giving rise to strict screening and fee-sharing requirements.[1] But for some reason, a clerk who is “personally and substantially” involved in a matter can still try to get a job from those parties, though you have to tell Judge first.[2] Because the MPRE is a pure multiple-choice exam, there’s no partial credit. There is a right answer: make sure you can get to it.

Ultimately, passing the MPRE is much easier than leading a consistently ethical career. Sure, the exam is closed book, but the stakes in real life are much, much higher. Be ethical—but for now, start with being right.

Charles Simonds is a 3L and Director of the Verdict.

1 See ABA Model Rule 1.11(c) (prohibiting former government lawyer with confidential information that would harm an adverse party from representing a client and imputing said conflict to the firm unless screening and fee-sharing requirements are met).

2 ABA Model Rule 1.12(b).

fields.title: Time for State and Local Prosecutors to Step Up
fields.preview_text: When we can no longer count on federal law enforcement to fairly and competently prosecute political corruption, white nationalist violence, civil rights abuses, and environmental crimes, state attorneys general and district attorneys from major cities should pick up the slack.
fields.content_html:
We are not living in normal times. In the post-Watergate and post-J. Edgar Hoover era, federal law enforcement’s nonpartisan nature has been taken for granted as a crucial norm for maintaining the integrity of our justice system. Under Republican and Democratic administrations alike, federal prosecutors in Washington and various U.S. Attorney’s Offices have brought cases against politicians of all stripes when they break campaign finance, anti-bribery, and foreign corruption laws. Most recently, the Justice Department under President Biden commenced criminal cases against fellow Democrats Robert Menendez, Eric Adams, and Congressman Henry Cuellar of Texas.

Republican and Democratic administrations often had different priorities. Republican AGs and U.S. Attorneys often focused on drugs, illegal immigration, and foreign terrorism, and Democratic AGs and U.S. Attorneys prioritized civil rights and financial crimes. However, even as prosecutorial priorities might change, we generally could count on the Justice Department, FBI, and other investigative agencies to enforce federal law regardless of whether it aligned with the priorities of the party currently occupying the Oval Office. For example, the George W. Bush Administration’s Justice Department prosecuted Enron’s senior executives and its complicit accounting firm, Arthur Andersen, despite the oil company’s close political ties to Republicans. And the Obama Administration’s Department of Justice continued to prosecute federal drug crimes and aided the Department of Homeland Security in prosecuting undocumented immigrants for unlawful entry while resisting pressure from some on the left to abandon such efforts.

But given the new Trump Administration’s behavior so far, independence for federal law enforcement appears to be out the window. Congress confirmed Kash Patel for FBI Director and then elevated the podcasting Trump-enthusiast Dan Bongino as Deputy Director. Both the FBI and DOJ began purging longtime career officials in leadership. Trump issued sweeping pardons of January 6th defendants and closed investigations or prosecutions of two Republican congressional allies (Rep. Andy Ogles of Tennessee and former Rep. Jeff Fortenberry of Nebraska). The nation’s law enforcement apparatus now appears to be operating entirely at the whims of the president. If Trump allies—be they members of Congress or sympathetic militia leaders—commit crimes against persons, property, or the state, we can no longer count on the Justice Department to hold them accountable. That’s where state law enforcement should step in.

Federal criminal law does not typically preempt state criminal law. Hence it’s not uncommon to see defendants on terrorism or drug charges facing both state and federal prosecutions. If the Justice Department declines to prosecute conduct illegal under state and federal statutes, state and local prosecutors—subject to jurisdiction and venue constraints—should be able to take up the case without triggering double jeopardy concerns on account of the dual sovereignty doctrine (reaffirmed by the Supreme Court in Gamble v. United States, 587 U.S. 678 (2019)). This may be obvious if a repeat of the Charlottesville riot or the George Floyd killing transpires; don’t expect this Justice Department to prosecute or sue culpable police officers after suspending all civil rights work. Local DAs are clearly aware of their ability to prosecute homicides. But many states have criminally enforceable public integrity and campaign finance laws, environmental and civil rights statutes, gun regulations, and domestic terrorism laws. Under normal administrations, state prosecutors might have been content to largely leave enforcement in these arenas to federal authorities, but that must change.

As an example, state and local prosecutors could investigate whether any of the newly pardoned January 6th insurrectionists organized in their states. A number of state and local prosecutors have already brought cases against 2020 election conspiracists who tried to manufacture fake certifications of Donald Trump’s victory in their states. Even though the attack on the Capitol occurred outside their jurisdiction, January 6th insurrectionists’ actions may still implicate state gun laws, domestic terrorism laws, and criminal conspiracy laws. The Oath Keepers, for instance, amassed weapons in a hotel in Virginia. Just because Donald Trump has decided to give insurrectionists, white nationalists, and corrupt political allies a pass from his administration does not mean the states have to follow suit.

Beyond the Capitol rioters, however, state prosecutors can and should bring corruption investigations. Whether for corporate or political allies, the second Trump administration has made it clear that corruption is a low priority and has already bent the law to give at least one sympathetic official a pass. Mayor Adams was indicted by the U.S. Attorney’s Office for the Southern District of New York in September 2024 following a prolonged investigation into misconduct by his campaign and several of his senior officials. From the get-go, Adams claimed he was the victim of a politicized prosecution and openly compared his situation to Trump’s battles with the Justice Department. While factually groundless, these complaints did not fall on deaf ears and acting officials in Washington quickly moved to quash the Adams case over the strong objection of career federal prosecutors in New York and D.C. Eight resignations and several strongly worded letters later, now the Justice Department is forced to defend its decision to seek the dismissal against an independent counsel appointed by Judge Ho.

In all likelihood, the federal government will not be forced to prosecute this case against Mayor Adams, but that doesn’t have to mean that he’s out of the woods. The Manhattan District Attorney, Alvin Bragg, or the state attorney general, Letitia James, could each open investigations of the mayor. However, the latter could apparently only bring criminal charges against Mayor Adams if she received a referral from a state or city agency. Neither is a stranger to politically sensitive prosecutions of national figures, and the DA has already been investigating several associates of Adams and recently indicted the mayor’s former “chief advisor” for bribery, conspiracy, and money laundering. Taking foreign donations while falsely claiming they came from New York donors to access matching public campaign funds violates state law as well. If Adams won’t be held accountable for corruption in federal court, there’s no reason he should escape justice in state court.

If either DA Bragg or AG James brings charges against Adams, it will send an important signal that the lack of federal accountability does not guarantee impunity writ large. The justice system in this country doesn’t work when it’s blatantly two-tiered. Those favored by the president or with connections to senior administration officials should not be permitted to openly operate outside the law while the rest of us face severe sanctions even for simple possession of controlled substances. By prosecuting Adams, state officials wouldn’t be engaging in a partisan affair. They would be doing their duty to ensure that laws are faithfully executed and evenly applied. If our leaders are not held accountable, how can we expect anyone else to respect the law, let alone follow it?

Joshua Nacht is a 3L at Columbia Law School.

fields.title: Law Revue’s “Honey, I Bought the Law School” Gets a High Pass for Humor and Heart
fields.writer: Daniel Sweat ’25, Gloria Yi ’25, Charles Simonds ’25, and Daniel Bugingo ’26
fields.content_html:
How could you entertain yourself with $25? Perhaps a ticket to an Oscar-winning film, maybe nosebleed Mets tickets. Anything would pale in comparison to this year’s Law Revue show, “Honey, I Bought the Law School.”

The show opened with “Lawrence of Columbia,” a video parody with a surreal transition into real-life Lawrence Oberemok ’25 coming on stage as Jiminy Cricket, the audience’s “conscience.” No time was wasted as the full cast came on for “Be Our Guest” (“Belle”), a flashy and well-choreographed opening, followed up by “The Partner’s New Groove” (“Perfect World”). From the beginning, Camilla Draycott LLM ’25 was an arresting stage presence. To get in character as the villainous Dean De Novo, Camilla stated: “I bought a red suit, and it transformed me.” (Camilla brings her experience from Oxford’s “In the Pink,” the university’s longest-running all-female a capella group, to the Law Revue.) Despite the name, Dean De Novo’s performance should only be reviewed for clear error.

The show’s highlights hit fast and hard. Arguably the best song of the show, “I Need a Gyro” (“I Need a Hero”) turned a simple pun into a star-powered choreographic sequence, with Jack Altman ’25, Wesley Schmidt ’25, and Noah Schaffir ’25 bringing infectious energy to the crowd. Wesley explained that “the Gyro choreography came together today. When you put people in a room together, magic happens.” If nothing else can convince you to come to Law Revue next time, let it be known that a man in a gyro costume bent over and threw ass tonight.

Another highlight was the “Themis Ad Break” Phantom of the Opera parody, replacing the eponymous Phantom with the Themis MPRE guy, Professor Zachary Kramer. The lead singer, Sasha Kudler ’25, nailed the whistle tone at the end of this track—twice. The background dancers, carrying large cutouts of Kramer’s head, were especially powerful (or scary, or arousing; responses were mixed). Throughout the night, the background dancers stole the show, whether it be the tank-topped background singers on “I Need a Gyro,” the can-can in “We’ve Got a Dream,” or the coordinating swaying on “I Won’t go to Big Law (Shoo Doop).”

There were some weak parts, though. The story didn’t make much sense, and the transition scenes sometimes dragged. There were some moments where conversation at the open bar came close to drowning out the actors. And the “CLSPN” skit unnecessarily came after our Dean’s Cup athletes. Roy Brooks ’25, a mainstay of Columbia’s team, wasn’t worried: “When I score 30 points five weeks from now, they’ll revise.”

But even as the hits slowed down as the show went on, the cast rallied for some magical moments. Another contender for top song was “I Don’t Know” (“Let It Go”), well-written, accurate, and thought-provoking. The refrain really makes you question the value of your law degree, but is ultimately the right answer to give to your probing relatives’ queries on worker’s comp and landlord disputes. (Frozen? More like Pozen. Or Bulman-Pozen? We write for the Verdict, not the Law Revue.)

We appreciated that Law Revue was barred up this semester, with multiple rap interludes.

The Verdict presents the Top Four Greatest Law Revue Rappers Alive

  1. Quimbee thee Stallion
  2. Whoever did the Latin verse (pretty sure this was Sasha Kudler ’25)
  3. Nishu Afobunor ’26
  4. Jack Altman ‘26

Other highlights included “Clerkship Sisters” (“The Schuyler Sisters,” with the memorable line “I do M&A baby, come merge with me”); calling standing “fake” in “Part of Your World” (one Fed Courts TA responded, “standing is not fake, it’s just a non-textually based, recently articulated, perennially-confused jurisdictional requirement that is routinely used to kick out cases the Court doesn’t like . . . wait a minute”); “Rainbow Connection” (listing respected jurists such as “Cardozo, Cardozo, and me”); a crowd-pleasing “Wine Club Supernova” (“Red Wine Supernova”); an iconic 3L-cast jump shot in “Ignoring Our Professors” (“We’re All in This Together”); and a strong finish with the impressive and vocally-demanding “Mouse Days Are Over” (“Dog Days Are Over”). A standing ovation, well-deserved, expressed the crowd’s enthusiasm.

We interviewed the cast and crew after the show. Ryan Witter ’26, one of the lead writers, noted that the show was largely written over a single weekend. Though the timeline was intense, the results were undeniable; when asked whether he preferred being an Articles Editor on the Columbia Law Review and being a writer for the Law Revue, he emphatically chose the latter.

The departing 3Ls were exhilarated while recognizing the meaning of their last Law Revue show. Lawrence Oberemok ’25 reflected that “Law Revue is one of the best parts of CLS” and that the moment was “bittersweet.” Ellie Baker ’25 echoed that sentiment, stating that Law Review was “the highlight of my time here.” While writing a show is hard, once she “gets 20 to 25 people in the same room for just the two days before a show, it’s magic.” The best part? “I love making people laugh. I can’t wait to come back.” Indeed, there was a strong Law Revue alumni presence. Shannon Hardy CLS ’23 talked about how much she wanted the Law Revue to survive the COVID years. It hasn’t just survived; it has thrived. And queuing up the show’s songs at Bar Revue for open karaoke was a nice touch.

Overall, the show was a romp. Punctuated by stellar vocal performances and fantastic costumes, the show delivered on all fronts. Parody, showmanship, artistic excellence. It’s hard not to recognize the genius and often surreal achievement of the Law Revue—especially after five beers. In the words of one audience member, “I don’t remember.”

5/5 Mickey ears, potential copyright violation notwithstanding.

Daniel Sweat ’25, Gloria Yi ’25, Charles Simonds ’25, and Daniel Bugingo ’26 contributed to reporting.

fields.title: Katrina Armstrong Bingo
fields.content_html:
Dear fellow members of the Columbia community,

This bingo card began as a joke earlier in the semester when the bulk of the administration’s communications were novellas about the plan to reopen campus in the near, but not too near, future. I probably don’t need to tell you that in the intervening period, the situation—and the ensuing communications—has become much bleaker. Stuck between a rock (defending our university, protesting the kidnapping of a Columbia student, taking a stand against an unconstitutional and authoritarian power grab) and a hard place (losing money), this administration has made its choice clear.

Remarkably, despite the severity of the present moment, our president has stayed true to her core guiding principle: saying the fewest things with the most words in the vaguest possible way.

We too find ourselves stuck between a rock (to laugh) and a hard place (to cry). Hopefully this bingo card helps us pick the former.

In solidarity,
Margaret

P.S. Please send me completed bingo cards if you play and win—it will make my day.

Margaret Broihier is a 1L at CLS.

fields.title: In Defense of the Bluebook
fields.content_html:
Cosmologists now believe that the last supermassive black holes will evaporate in a googol years (10100 years), leaving behind a bleak cosmic landscape without heat or light that will likely continue on infinitely. Yet even then, my hatred of the Bluebook will endure, echoing across the timeless void of an empty, barren universe.

I know what you’re thinking: “Why would you begin your purported defense of the Bluebook with this scathing attack?” The answer is two-fold.

First, I am a big fan of the misdirect.

Secondly, and more importantly, I have come to believe that the Kafkaesque monstrosity known only as “the Bluebook” actually represents one of the most important educational tools for aspiring lawyers. Given my own well-established distaste, I feel that I am uniquely qualified to mount a reasoned defense. I want to take this opportunity to make my case.

Like many of you, I have spent much of the last two years Bluebooking for a journal—in my case, the Columbia Human Rights Law Review. As a result, I have spent an uncomfortable number of hours navigating the labyrinthine machinations of legal academia’s most illustrious style guide, first as a 2L Staffer and now as a Managing Editor.

I have experienced all the myriad joys that the Bluebook has to offer: the agony of navigating Rule 21 to cite an international source; the frustration of vainly searching for an appropriate analogue for a foreign statute somewhere in the depths of Table 2; the sinking despair of learning that I wasn’t using “supra” correctly. In other words, I have shared in the trials and tribulations of all law students since time immemorial (i.e., circa 1926).

Part of what makes the Bluebook so infuriating is that it is, to borrow a phrase, “arbitrary and capricious.” It contains numerous discrepancies that appear to serve no function other than to trip up the unfamiliar. Rule 18.2.2 long ago abandoned the need to write “available at” before a URL, yet several jurisdictions in T2 retain this redundant archaism.1 The word “Law” should be abbreviated as “L.,” unless it begins the abbreviated sentence in which case it should be written as “Law”—but this exception does not apply to any other word in T6. You can use “supra” for almost any source, but heaven forbid we catch you trying to use it for a court case. The list goes on.

I am not the first to arrive at such an unflattering conclusion. The legendary poet and street philosopher Judge Richard A. Posner famously decried the Bluebook as “elaborate but not purposive,” an example of “the tendency of human beings to mindless elaboration of social practices,” and guilty of an “un-American” obsession with uniformity.2 He went on to lament that “[i]nstead of learning the Uniform Commercial Code the student learns the Uniform Citation Code, which is almost as long, and far more arbitrary.”3

Yet herein lies the crux of my defense—a lot of life is governed by arbitrary and capricious standards. And there is perhaps no profession more susceptible to such standards than the notoriously gatekept world of the lawyer. This is true even for the relatively narrow realm of formatting requirements. Most jurisdictions have their own style guides, many of which appear to impose equally unpredictable standards. (What possible benefit could there be in demanding that we add two spaces after each period?) As lawyers, we are expected to quickly adapt to new formatting standards, regardless of whether they are intuitive, logical, or even justifiable.

But I would expand this argument well beyond the auspices of style. Our careers will often hinge on truly arbitrary factors. Sometimes this will be to our benefit—perhaps we are interested in exactly the right area of law to qualify for a generous grant, or maybe we get more face-time with a partner because we enjoy the same pastimes. In other cases, we will suffer negative consequences through no fault of our own. Either way, the most we can usually do is to read the room and adapt to the system as it is.

Humans are imperfect animals, and lawyers are not insulated from this imperfection simply because we go through seven or more years of post-high school education. Moreover, there seems to be a plethora of reasons why lawyers are particularly prone to imposing arbitrary standards on each other, some more defensible than others. There is value in consistency and clarity. Focusing on form injects objective criteria into the inherently subjective nature of many legal disputes. Imposing artificial restrictions on language can foster the development of common norms and values. Plus, let’s not forget how fun it can be to watch other people go through the same struggles we faced (regardless of whether those struggles are themselves intrinsically worthwhile).

I firmly believe that the Bluebook’s primary value, and perhaps its only real defense, lies in its ability to teach us how to efficiently navigate such standards with grace and humility (or in my case, with a seething, entropy-defying rage). The Bluebook accomplishes this in at least three ways.

First, it requires users to develop a keen attention to detail in a distinctly legal context. There are standards (both mandatory and permissive) governing even the most minute details, such as which comma in “see, e.g.,” should be italicized. While I cannot imagine a world in which an italicized comma will have any outcome-determinative effect, there are plenty of other, seemingly trivial details that carry much more weight. And even punctuation is sometimes dispositive. The First Circuit case of O’Connor v. Oakhurst Dairy famously turned on an ambiguity resulting from the omission of an Oxford comma in the underlying statutory provision.4

Second, and relatedly, the Bluebook teaches us how to be thorough—to dot our I’s, cross our T’s, and italicize only uncommon Latin phrases (Sed quis est dicere quid sit commune?). It is not enough that you check Rule 16 when citing an academic article, as you must also follow the rules governing capitalization (Rule 8), abbreviations (Tables 6, 10, and 13), and subdivisions (Rule 3). Is there any particular reason why it is necessary to go through so many steps for a footnote that most people will likely never read?5 Not as far as I can tell. As the venerable D.J.6 Posner once observed, “readers are not interested in citation form.”7 But the obvious benefit of this convoluted system is that it inculcates a tendency to triple check your own work and leave no stone unturned. Since the substantive law governing a dispute will rarely be contained in a single, convenient place, these habits can be crucial for our legal careers.

Finally, the Bluebook teaches us how to navigate a system that is both persnickety (e.g., by requiring us to make sure the periods in certain signals are italicized for the apparent benefit of the three people reading this who can tell the difference) and yet somehow underinclusive. For instance, while Rule 21.7 provides six pages of detailed instructions for citing United Nations materials, in my experience authors cite to authorities that do not fall into any enumerated category more often than not. As far as I can tell, this is not a reflection of the Bluebook per se, but rather a necessary consequence of the ever-increasing complexity of sources.8 The more we try to categorize and separate the world into discrete, self-contained categories, the more the world seems to defy us.

This last skill is deceptively important for anyone who wishes to navigate the U.S. legal system. When faced with ambiguity, we must interpret. We must appeal to the policies that informed the rule (here, clarity, ease of access, and superciliousness) and make value judgments accordingly. We must develop instincts to guide our decisions, and we must learn to trust those instincts.

In short, the Bluebook is many things: the epitome of human hubris, the physical embodiment of the term “Sisyphean,” and an atrocity worthy of international condemnation, to name but a few. Yet it offers us an unparalleled opportunity to develop essential skills and habits in a relatively risk-free environment (assuming you don’t consider the potential of bringing down the wrath of an irate Managing Editor to be a “risk”). For that reason, I believe we should all raise a glass to this ignoble institution.

Godspeed, Bluebook. I’ll see you in hell.

Michael Weaver is a 3L at CLS.

1 For example, the Portuguese Constitution and certain court cases (T2.34) or Japanese courts cases (T2.24).

2 Richard A. Posner, Goodbye to the Bluebook, 53 U. Chi. L. Rev. 1343, 1343, 1349 (1986).

3 Id. at 1349.

4 See O’Connor v. Oakhurst Dairy, 851 F.3d 69, 70 (1st Cir. 2017) (“For want of a comma, we have this case.”).

5 For example, why are you reading this? Go back to the main text.

6 Short for “Dicta Jurist.”

7 Richard A. Posner, The Bluebook Blues (Reviewing Harvard Law Review Association, The Bluebook: A Uniform System of Citation (19th ed. 2010)), 120 Yale L.J. 850, 853 (2011).

8 But see id. at 859–60 (arguing that the Bluebook has expanded in part because of its “planned-obsolescence business model”).

fields.title: What the Taxpayer Said to Marshall McLuhan
fields.content_html:
Medium and message,
form and substance,

syntax and semantics,
body and soul,
“a prepaid forward” and “a loan,”

what computers do and what humans do,
structure and function,
“abandonment” and “sale or exchange,”

text and subtext,
politeness and respect,
fame and (not much),

form and substance,
medium and message,

are actually totally different

Daniel Bugingo is a 2L and a Writer for the Verdict.

fields.title: Advisory Opinion: Post on LinkedIn about Summer Internships?
fields.content_html:
“Do I really have to post on LinkedIn about my summer internship? What if I don’t have one yet but just want to post?”

Dear Reader,

No. You really don’t have to. But, it is also okay to be proud of yourself and want to share it. I always believed in you (say it back!). But anyway. Whether you want to post or not, if you use LinkedIn to network, you should probably add your summer gig to your profile. But there is an option to do so without sharing it as a post. If you want to be subtle about it.

If you don’t have a summer internship lined up, but want to post, you have some options. Maybe share a recent legal win in the field you are interested in. Or explain what you’re interested in and ask if anyone has suggestions for an organization or firm that matches your interests. I haven’t tried this, but you miss every shot you don’t shoot, etc. You could also update your profile with a new headshot and let those likes roll in. Also, I know you didn’t ask . . . but just keep applying! All you need is one. You got this.

P.S. If you like to post publicly with no rhyme or reason, you should apply to write for the Verdict.

Byeeee,
Kat

Katerina Kakkis is a 3L and a Contributor for the Verdict.

fields.title: Some Counsel for Future Counsel
fields.content_html:
1. You made it. Stop worrying for the sake of worrying. You're good enough and you will be fine.
  2. Law school is nothing like practice. Do what you want for your goals, but don't really think about preparing for your career. It won't happen during law school.
  3. You have complete control over your time right now. That won't always be the case. Don't let yourself miss memories for schoolwork, which you can plan flexibly.
  4. You're not stuck in your section. Join clubs and meet people after 1L fall. Columbia is a big place and your people are probably here, even if CLS didn't pair you up.
  5. Don't take yourself too seriously. You don't always have to play the role of a "law student" with that one defining trait. You're still just a person who goes to school.
  6. It's not gonna get better after law school. Whether you do Big Law or PI, your free time is about to decrease drastically. Use it now. Seriously.
  7. Don't take on responsibilities that won't meaningfully help you achieve goals but will meaningfully limit your life. Know what you're signing up for. *cough* journals *cough*
  8. Just have fun during 3L. It's like an extended summer camp and the cruel reality of legal practice will hit you soon enough. You've earned a break.
  9. Do big stuff with your school breaks that you won't be able to do later. You don't get weeks at a time off in real life.
  10. Please, just enjoy these years. One day you will be told to leave your own birthday dinner to complete another 17 "urgent" assignments and cry yourself to sleep at 4 am. For now, you just have to read a few cases and hang out with a bunch of other nerds your age during the week. Let yourself enjoy that.

P.S. If you join cool things like Law Revue, Video Game Club, Murder Mystery Club, and Softball Club, you're guaranteed to get straight A's and be super popular and hot.

Dylan Gaffney received his J.D. from CLS in 2024.

fields.title: Community Highlight: Specialized Moot Court Guide
fields.content_html:
COMMUNITY HIGHLIGHT:

Lucía Bautista, 2L and Academic Chair for LaLSA, put together this 1L Specialized Moot Court Guide with perspectives and advice from students who participated in specialized moot courts. Lucía and other Academic Chairs across affinity groups collaborate to put on events and create resources to help students feel comfortable and confident in the classroom. This guide is a great example of that mentorship mission in action. Thanks, Lucía!

fields.title: This Week's Advice
fields.content_html:
“Getting involved at CLS was significant in my growth not just as a student, but as an individual. Being around people with similar interests is a stimulating environment to be in, but I also highly recommend seeking diverse perspectives. CSIL is a community where we embrace international law’s inherent diversity, and this is reflected through the various speakers and events we host throughout the semester, which you are more than welcome to attend. Everyone is celebrated in CSIL!” —Emmanuella Antwi-Buosiako, President, Columbia Society for International Law

“When choosing which organizations to get involved with, I mainly considered how responsive and intentional the organization is with its career and community-building programming. I enjoyed the mix that ELS provided through cross-mixers with our law schools' environmental student organizations, career panels with environmental changemakers, and conversations with litigators and youth plaintiffs pushing the envelope of environmental law. Whether you're a devoted member or attend a single event a semester, ELS is always a great space, as it is beautiful to share community with other law students passionate about environmental justice and using the law to promote a more sustainable and equitable society.” —Amado A. Castillo, Publicity Chair, Environmental Law Society

“1Ls should try out as many student groups and organizations as you can or are interested in! So much of 1L is dictated for you from classes to professors to schedule, so organizations and clubs are a great way to create friendships and stay engaged in the communities and movements that drew you to law school. For example, if you are passionate about the separation of church and state, attending a Secularism Society event can get you plugged into recent events and allow you to ask questions of experts in this area. This fall, we will be putting on events in partnership with Americans United for the Separation of Church and State and also having a panel with professors such as Kate Redburn.” —Tyler Henry, 3L Representative, Secularism Society

“Participating in student groups has been the most rewarding thing I've done in law school. Through FedSoc I've had opportunities I couldn't have imagined beforehand, on top of professional and academic assistance. Law school can be a solipsistic experience unless you work to prevent that from happening. If you're interested in a student group, I would encourage you to join—you'll find a way to handle the workload and will make friends who will gladly help you out!” —Noah Farley, President, Federalist Society

“Fall semester of 1L is a great way to join groups related to the interests or identities you bring to law school, or groups that work on topics that you’re curious about learning more about at CLS. Though it can seem daunting with so many to choose from, joining a student org is a great way to meet upper-year students and people from other sections. This semester, If/When/How will be hosting discussions about current legal issues in the reproductive rights landscape, as well as curating volunteer opportunities for students to volunteer and reproductive rights-related referenda across the country.” —Makayla Haussler, Co-President, If/When/How

“Law school is a daunting experience, but because we face the challenge together, it provides countless opportunities to find a lasting, meaningful community. The Disabled Law Students Association is committed to welcoming everyone on campus with that exact goal in mind: to support our peers with friendship and guidance in navigating CLS with a special focus on the needs specific to the disabled community. There will continue to be challenges to this goal of ensuring our classmates receive the support they rightfully and legally deserve. This is why DLSA exists: to provide students with opportunities to serve as advocates, to engage in the practice of disability law, and to make the Columbia campus more accessible for everyone.” —Larissa Danovitch, President, William Chapman-Black, Treasurer, and Reza Sarrafian, Board Member, Disabled Law Students Association

“As a 1L, I was drawn to the Columbia International Arbitration Association (CIAA) because it offered a welcoming space where anyone, regardless of prior knowledge, can learn about this dynamic area of dispute resolution. CIAA stands out as one of the most vibrant, culturally enriching, and faculty-supported student groups on campus. Not only are our many LLM members incredible resources on all things international, but they are also a personable crowd eager to explore New York with us. Additionally, CIAA annually hosts Columbia Arbitration Day, a premier international arbitration conference that brings together scholars, practitioners, and students from across the globe to explore new advances and revisit enduring themes in the field." —Reza Sarrafian, J.D. Vice President, Columbia International Arbitration Society

Natalie Smith is a 3L at CLS.

fields.title: “The Work Is Mysterious and Important”: Severance and Big Law
fields.content_html:
On Thursday, March 20, 2025, Apple TV aired the finale of its highly acclaimed TV drama, Severance. Severance follows the lives of Lumon Enterprises employees who undergo severance, a process that separates their work and personal lives into two distinct consciousnesses. Their work personas, known as “Innies,” know nothing about their life outside of work, and their outside personas, known as “Outies,” know nothing about their life inside the office. The show follows the Innies’ struggle for autonomy and independence. Much has been written about Severance’s critique of the modern corporate world. The Lumon office is notably austere: All its walls are white and pictureless, and its hallways are seemingly endless. The Innies’ employers consistently proclaim that they are like a “family,” with strange, forced bonding procedures that the Innies find uncomfortable and reject. Severance’s depiction of corporate life is remarkably accurate compared to a job relevant to most Columbia Law Students: the Big Law associate.

One of the most striking similarities between being an Innie at Lumon and a Big Law associate is the idea that the workday never ends. Innies’ consciousnesses are turned off when they leave the office, at which point the Outie consciousness takes over. This means that Innies are constantly on the clock; their workday never ends because their entire existence is confined to working at Lumon. Big Law associates notoriously pull long hours, often neglecting family or social obligations to meet an emergency deadline or appease an angry partner. How different is this from Dylan’s Innie, who never got to experience living with his wife and children because he never got a life outside of the office? A Big Law associate is no stranger to the level of sacrifice demanded from every Innie.

Another parallel between Severance and Big Law is the work itself. The main cast works in Lumons’s Macrodata Refinement (MDR) department, spending their days sorting through seemingly random numbers. Whenever employees question the meaning of their work, their peers and supervisors respond with the same Lumon-engineered response: “The Work Is Mysterious and Important.” Big Law associates often experience a similar detachment from the meaning and impact of their work. First-year associates spend hours doing document review or drafting contracts, rarely understanding the larger legal strategy, consequences or context behind their efforts. While Severance doesn't reveal the true nature of MDR’s work until the second season’s finale, the viewer senses that whatever it is, it can’t be good. First-year associates may get the same feeling: Doing document review without recognizing the larger implications of a case can feel similarly eerie, especially when large firms are working to defend large companies committing human rights violations or capitulating to Trump’s demands to dissolve DEI departments despite long-standing commitments to them.

Of course, getting severed and becoming a Big Law associate are not the same. At least in Severance, you clock out at 5. While the show’s premise is a heightened dystopian exaggeration with moments of strangeness and camp, its similarities with modern corporate culture are undeniable. The isolation from family and friends, the lack of sense of purpose, and the demand for loyalty to a corporation at the expense of personal identity are familiar to those working in corporate law. These parallels raise an interesting question: At what point does the job stop being just a job and start becoming an all-encompassing existence? For many Big Law associates, this question might hit too close to home.

Elijah Pitt is a 1L and a Writer for the Verdict.

fields.title: Advisory Opinion: I bought a ticket to Barristers’ Ball
fields.content_html:
“I bought a ticket to Barristers’ Ball, but am unsure about the whole thing. How do I make the most of it?”

Dear Reader,

First, I missed you. And if you missed me, make sure to submit questions so we never have to be parted again. Anyway. Can’t wait to see you on Saturday! As a general matter I think it is good to have some reservations about law school-wide social events because years from now, you will actually have to work with some of these people! Also, you might have heard about last year’s long line to get into the venue (“Linegate”) and the difficulty of reaping the full benefits of the open bar. Well, a source close to the center of BB operations confirmed that those issues have been addressed. More bars, more check-in staff, and even some things nobody asked for! Like a live saxophonist, casino games (if you’re feeling lucky), and rain (maybe bring an umbrella). So, keeping that all in mind, let’s make the most of your Barristers’ Ball.

What to wear! Read the Senate emails for more info on the theme and dress exchange info. I suggest taking this unique opportunity to dress up and feel/look good. Also wear comfy shoes, please. I do not want your dogs out. Try to organize a group of people with whom you can commute and prepare for the evening. Maybe create a shared doc with some predictions for the night. While not critical, a pre-ball gathering is so helpful if you’re bringing a non-law school date. They are a goldfish and you must acclimate them to the law school tank slowly. The law school friends you know best is a good place to start.

Finally, do not miss out on the free food and photobooths. Last year, I focused on the open bar and neglected these two critical resources. Also, Senate drops all the photobooth photos during finals and it’s such an excellent hour of procrastination, so don’t be selfish and give us content.

Standing with you,
Kat

Katerina Kakkis is a 3L and a Contributor for the Verdict.

fields.title: An Interview with Professor Susan Sturm
fields.content_html:
Professor Susan Sturm is the George M. Jaffin Professor of Law and Social Responsibility here at Columbia Law School, and her life’s work is focused on advancing racial equity and full participation in institutions. A few of you might have been to her book talk a couple weeks ago on “What Might Be: Confronting Racism to Transform Our Institutions.” Professor Sturm is also a co-chair of the Davis Polk Leadership Institute. Thank you so much for joining us.

Can you describe your journey: going to law school, working at a firm, and becoming a professor at Columbia Law?

Professor Sturm: When I went to law school, I did not think I would become a teacher of law. I am a first-generation college graduate and first in my family to go to law school. I found law school, especially the first year, to be a very alienating experience. I thought law school would have some relationship to justice, but I had to search to find conversations that really allow that to be the center of gravity. My criminal law teacher stopped calling on me because I wanted to raise these questions.

I’ve always cared a lot about learning as a vehicle for change, the importance of ideas, and the importance of connecting knowledge of different kinds. And I actually used writing and researching as a way to grapple with the limitations of what I was seeing when I worked for the special master court system. Writing both helped me to understand what was going on and to treat something problematic as not given, opening it up and having it be understood and questioned. I also met Martha Minow, who is like a genetically engineered academic and a really wonderful person, who kept saying to me, “You’re meant to do this. You can do what you really care about by joining the faculty and defining the role in a way that makes sense to you.”

I worked for a couple of small boutique law firms that did a lot of employment discrimination and housing discrimination work. I found it interesting, but also frustrating, because your work was so dictated by whether a case could be brought and whether that issue was live, and as soon as that was no longer the case you had to move on to another issue. I felt like you couldn’t get your hands fully around deep issues that I really wanted to address. That led me into teaching. And that was a great decision. As you probably know, I love this job. It’s doing a wonderful job if you’re interested in social change, and you don’t allow the rules to define everything you do.

Two of the key themes found in your CV, your writing, and our conversation, are the idea of using law as a tool for social change, and the idea that the system of law is meant to keep the status quo in place. How do you square these two?

That contradiction—that law is an instrument for pursuing justice and that law is one of the major ways to maintain an unjust status quo—has been at the heart of my experience of law from the time I entered law school and up to the present. It’s actually one of the paradoxes of anti-racism that I wrote about in What Might Be: Confronting Racism to Transform Our Institutions.

One of those paradoxes is a paradox of racialized institutions. Look at Martin Luther King’s words: He actually talks about this contradiction in the Letter from Birmingham Jail. The paradox is that law is the effort to have our institutions work their way toward actually being able to claim justice even though law is the instrument that has always been used to advance the interests of those narrowly holding onto power, to subjugate people who are not fully recognized, to maintain the simultaneous declaration of democracy and freedom, while in the same declaration excluding people from participating in that.

We cannot achieve social change without engaging with the idea that at the very least, law is standing in the way. Lawyers, even lawyers for social change, can be standing in the way by occupying space, as if we have all the answers without involving people directly impacted by mass incarceration, by racism, by immigration injustice. If they are not actually involved, not only in telling their story, but in shaping what we do, then we, as lawyers, are actually perpetuating the power dynamics that have produced the current inequality. We have to be involved at the very least, to get law off the backs of people when it is functioning that way, and to use the instruments of law, which are among the tools that can stand as a bulwark against injustice, against totalitarianism. At the same time you have to always be conscious, as lawyers, how we are carrying, in our very way of practicing, some of the ways of subjugating people or maintaining the status quo that we’re trying to change. We have to maintain that kind of self-critical, humble stance, as we are also embracing law as a tool among many to advance social justice, racial justice, and the other values that are so important to a genuine democracy.

I think one of the most important themes in your book is the idea of the “what might be,” imagining a system that is not littered with inequality, injustice, and racism. Do you think that working to achieve a system of law that looks like that helps resolve that paradox?

Well, a paradox by definition cannot be resolved. A paradox is different from a dilemma. A dilemma are two exclusive, mutually exclusive choices. You have to pick one or the other; you can’t do both. A paradox are two contradictory tools or practices, both of which are true, and both of which have to be held.

When we create—I call them microspaces of justice, what adrienne maree brown, in Emerging Strategy, calls a fractal—when we create those spaces, we do resolve some of the paradoxes because we eliminate the conditions that create those contradictions. But the contradictions are built into our culture. We want to identify with a group, even as we really insist on our individuality and are really resisting being defined by it. That is just built into the nature of human existence.

So our goal is not to resolve the paradoxes; it is to figure out how to hold them. If we know that one of the paradoxes is the paradox of racialized power and the way power operates to exclude, we can try to redefine the way power is exercised so that power is shared, so that you don’t have to choose between stepping in and making decisions yourself, the way that will push out the people who need to be involved: people of color, people directly affected by injustice. It will not push them out because we all have a place at the table.

We have to recognize that we’re always going to come up against these contradictions, and that we have to find a way to do both things: practice law for justice, even as we de-legitimate the law.

So how do we do that? We form groups that enable us to do different things at the same time. We develop some muscle of not always having to be right, of holding messiness and complexity, of making mistakes and recovering from them. That is a practice that we have to develop over the individual level and also at the level of our organizations.

You cannot create an organization where, if you make a mistake, you’re going to be shamed. As long as you’re pushing for the common goal, you get to, as I have so many times, with the help of my students, be called out for mistakes that you have made and given the opportunity to do better. That’s how I think we do it. We don’t expect to resolve them. We try to move in that direction of holding them both and seeing whether we can change the background conditions of the system, so that the contradictions are not quite as stark as they are in our institutions.

You seem to not buy into the idea that law is inherently conservative, or that a lawyer has to maintain the status quo. What do you think of the concept of movement lawyering? Do you consider yourself a movement lawyer?

I love this question. There are different definitions of law that are built into your question, right? One definition of law is what courts say, what legislatures pronounce, what administrative agencies promulgate. That is certainly one form of law.

But I think about law in a way that I learned from my mentor, Robert Cover, which is as a theory of change. It’s about the relationship between the is, which is the unacceptable status quo; the ought, which is the vision of the world that we would like to see; and law is the connective tissue that tries to move the is closer to the ought. When we think about law that way, we already have a contradiction, because law on the books is part of what needs to be changed. Institutions, as they currently operate, are part of what needs to be changed. And in this dynamic relationship, we should continue to be pushing toward the ought. That is a different idea of law. So with that idea in mind, does that make me a movement lawyer?

I think that also depends on what we think about as a movement. I’d like to think that I am part of a movement that is housed within the institutions and pushing to use organizing and network building and community building and mutual accountability, not only within my own institution, but across institutions and with communities to push the system to change and push those who are in positions of formal power to change, and also to take power for ourselves to change what we can change within our own communities, within our own institutions, within our own classrooms.

If we define movement lawyering that way, sign me up! I’m a movement lawyer.

Often when we think about movement lawyering, we think about large community-led social movements like Black Lives Matter or the Civil Rights Movement. I don’t think that I could legitimately claim that I am that kind of movement lawyer: I am not in the streets, I am not out there in the communities. I brought communities into the law school, and I’m working with them in the context of transforming the way we do our work here.

I think we need to broaden our understanding of what a movement lawyer is. I think the way we traditionally understand is super important, but I think we have to have new movements. We see that right now. Protest is very risky for a lot of people, and it’s not having its intended impact all the time. It’s sometimes used as a basis for increasing repression rather than pushing people to think differently. I think we need to think about movements in much more capacious ways that include work that we do with and between institutions, and that involve people in all kinds of positions, including people who are still on the streets protesting, pushing public awareness. It’s going to require many people from many different positions, using whatever power and influence they have to come together and push for change in a different way.

And so that would make all of us potentially movement lawyers. But that is a label we have to earn. You have to be working in a collaborative way that includes people directly impacted by the piece you’re trying to make to call yourself a movement lawyer.

You’ve noted the importance of working with organizers and working within the activism protest space.

You work with the Broadway Advocacy Coalition a lot through this process to facilitate [Theater of Change], but also get people to be involved. Do you think that your work with organizations like the Broadway Advocacy Coalition and doing Theater of Change has informed your ability to be a movement lawyer, added something to your conception of the law, what it means to be a lawyer?

Absolutely. The Broadway Advocacy Coalition has both built on work that I had been doing and has really shaped what I’ve done since then. Part of the way this took shape is that the recurrent state of killings of black men led a group of six Black artists to say, “We want to do something, but we don’t just want to perform or just do fundraisers. We want to do something that uses artistry to make change.” So they came to me as the Director of the Center for Institutional and Social Change, and we formed this partnership.

What has been really transformative about doing the work in the Theater of Change is bringing together these three different groups: law students; people directly impacted by racism, immigration, or mass incarceration who are advocating the change; and performing artists. And we become equals in that space. It’s not like there’s one group in charge, just taking information from other groups and feeding it into their way of working. It’s really about creating cross-fertilization across these integral groups.

And so I saw law students being transformed by that space to say, “Well, I want creativity. I’m remembering what I can do when I am invited to go beyond CREAC, you know, not throw it out, but go beyond.” And I saw artists say, “Wow, I can really make my message so much more powerful because I’m involving people directly impacted in the telling of that story. And I am working with law students who can really help me tell it where it matters, and in a form that people I don’t understand will actually listen to.”

I think something that I noticed working in those spaces is that you kind of come in thinking that as a law student, you’re supposed to be the legal expert. But you’re talking to people who’ve been impacted by the system for 15 years, and like they’ve lived it. And that experience, it’s hard to know that when you’re coming at it from one perspective, or only viewing that from an academic lens.

Building on that really important point: One of the surprises to me in doing this work is that, being a law student in this work rather than being a lawyer is actually a tremendous plus.

Part of what I have learned over and over again is that people directly impacted by incarceration, immigration, and racism have had some pretty negative experiences with lawyers and our legal system. They don’t trust us. They’ve had the experience of having a lawyer who represents them, not really listening to them or treating them as a human being, just taking what they need in order to speak on their behalf. So they’re pretty distrustful of lawyers.

They don’t have that same view about law students. There’s a kind of openness, and just the fact that it didn’t take very long for law students to realize, “Wait a minute, they know more than I about certain things; I want to be part of this, but I don’t want to be the one telling them what they need to do in order to achieve their goal.” So the people that I’ve worked with in the Theater of Change and people who were directly impacted prefer working with law students who have backup support from lawyers.

And also they love the idea that they’re part of helping us learn how to be more effective movement lawyers, lawyers for change, so that when people graduate law school they’re not going to have to go through a process of unlearning how to be an effective partner in this work. They see themselves, as in that dual role of both learning from law students who know how to do research, who have access to legal knowledge, and also helping to shape and inform law students so that they will be more effective. And that makes it very exciting for them.

Moving into the concept of movement lawyering today, I think it’s interesting, the contradiction; we’re seeing a lot of legal institutions and concepts like the rule of law eroded, which is sort of a good and bad thing for a movement lawyer. On one hand, we want to see the systems that have been used to oppress people of color leave. But on the other hand, we’re seeing the lack of rule of law and the lack of respect for institutions being used to harm people. How do you square that as a lawyer? And what do you think our role is in this time?

If I had really concrete answers to that question, you should probably not trust anything I say, because there are no answers right now. Anyone who has one is probably insufficient to the task or pushing in the wrong direction. But obviously there are things that we need to do. First of all, it’s important to both challenge the destruction of institutions that we’ve relied on to set boundaries and create space for autonomy, recognizing that our legal institutions have never [been genuinely just] but at the same time to use the fact that there are things being dismantled that we would have been very critical of, that we would want to build differently going forward.

You know the idea that controlled burning actually helps create space for new growth? This is not controlled burning. This is a forest fire with the purpose being to destroy everything. But if we can think about and claim the productive aspects of starting fresh, then some of the work that we need to be doing is in that contradiction.

What we put in its place is going to be imperfect. But I think it’s really important for people to be protecting the institutions that are so fundamental to being able to pursue democratic values. We all have to find our place in this world, right? Some people are going to be the gladiators, who are really going to be resisting the efforts to run roughshod over these fundamental values that are so key to democracy and to maintain respect for legal systems, that discipline violence and the exercise of power.

At the same time, my natural place is more in how do we build what we want to see. And I think this really is a time when lawyers and legal actors and community members and activists need to be thinking very hard about what we want to put in place when the opportunity presents itself. And that means both thinking about what we want to do right now to experience communities that support people who are being targeted, that support the ability to continue to ask questions about race and racism; to think about how issues of gender and sexuality need to be part of these issues—I use the language of full participation—what do we need to do right now so that people, regardless of their race, their background, their gender, their religion, their sexuality, can access, participate in and thrive and feel safe in the institutions we currently have. What aspects do we really want to put back into place once we have a chance?

And what are the things that we need to do differently? Do we really want to just have one person appointed as a DEI officer who’s going to be a responsibility for trying to advance full participation when that person is not part of actually making these most significant decisions in an institution? Maybe we want to rethink how we advance full participation in our institutions in a way that will make it more real. That will make it more structural, more able to get at what are the injustices that are built into the current system.

So we can’t just let that go. We have to build that. And I think students are really important to that. You are the future, and it’s tomorrow, not in a long time. You’re the ones who are going to have to inherit the mess that we currently have. And you need to be part of the project of building that fabric and building that constituency. And you all know how to organize. You really do, in ways that go beyond what my generation knows how to do so. I think we need these multi-generational collaborations that are going to be built on these strengths. I have the value of experience being at this for a long time, and being in a position where some people will listen to me. But I don’t know what you all know. I can’t do what you all can do. That’s part of what we need to do, come together across our different locations.

The piece about law students is especially important for sustaining momentum because you’re kind of building the next generation of lawyers. But I wanted to talk specifically about law students’ role. Law students in general are indoctrinated into the legal institutions that many lawyers are trying to change, especially Columbia Law students, right? The institution that we’re working in is kind of [pessimism]-leading at worst, and hostile at best, to everything that’s happening with the Trump administration, down to the affronts on the rule of law and the attacks on the freedom of speech in protests. What do you think our role is, what feasibly can we do?

Let me just say that I think your primary role as a student is to prepare yourself for a lifetime of social justice.

The responsibility for this institution is with the people who are here in the long run. So I don’t think it should be on the back of law students to make sure that this institution remains an institution of higher education. I personally think it is legitimate and desirable for people to take the medium view and say, “What do I need to do to prepare myself for a lifetime of social justice?” and not to be fully sidetracked by what’s going on around us at Columbia Law School and law schools in general.

You might disagree with that. I really respect and admire people who are making what’s happening in their own institution the focal point of their mind here. But I look around the room. You have to get what we need to be able to do that work, and that’s different than saying, I just want to put my head down, get my law degree, and go make a lot of money. This is different. I want to take a view of thinking not only in a moment, but thinking long-term.

On law schools and higher education more generally, my hope is that we will also step out and see why what we do now is so important to the continued legitimacy and efficacy of higher education institutions, and the ability to protest, the ability to speak openly, the ability not to be policed for what you believe, what you say, what you do, what the politics are.

If we lose that, we are no longer an institution of higher education. We’re a trade school. That’s critically important. For law students making sure that you’re able to do that while you’re here and speaking out about ways in which you think that’s not happening, I think that’s really important.
