I also worry about my students. I worry about the impact of students who are not U.S. citizens who may be risking completing their education. I worry about being in such a time warp at this moment, that you won’t be able to get what you need in order to have a full benefit of your years of legal education. In that way, I realize I am someone who cares very much about my students. That can be sometimes limiting in terms of saying go out there, put your body on the line, so what if you get arrested. I see the impact on some of the people who have taken those risks in the past, and it hasn’t produced the outcome in terms of social change that they were willing to sacrifice themselves for

And so it’s important to take a long view, and to ask more than “What do I want to see happen? And what am I angry about? What do I profoundly disagree with?” All of which are really important things to articulate, express, talk about, and then really develop a theory of change and pursue your overall long term effort to be an activist for change.

So I think that’s a very personal decision. And I think every law student needs to be asking the question. How do I grapple with the attack on the rule of law, how do I grapple with the attack on free speech and academic freedom, lawyering for people the government disagrees with, being able to advance issues of equity and inclusion? We all need to be thinking about that, when our own space is pushing back on that. And, doing it in a way where you can connect the dots from the short term to where you want to be in the long run.

I think the note on individuality is important. Everyone has a different capacity for what they can do, but they can handle themselves and everyone can ask themselves questions.

(Audience) Something that you said earlier on kind of stuck with me, the idea that, regardless of what institution we go into, we become affiliated with in the future, it’s about creating the space, opening up the conversation, bringing people in. How do you think we should think about doing so in an institution that might not have traditionally been very welcoming to these outside voices, might not even think there’s a need to have other people who are not in the institution be part of the conversation?

This is where doing a real theory of change analysis and [rule of law] need to be very [first steps]. You come into an institution and want to have a conversation. Our first impulse might be, oh, let me just post it on the calendar and see who comes. I think that’s probably a mistake to just do it like that. I think you first have to figure out the landscape. Who is in the institution? Who’s in dialogue, not only those inside the institution, but also stakeholders of the institution? Where could I have the conversation in a way that would feel authentic and have integrity?

Then, identify a couple of other people who maybe are in different positions than you are. Because if you can’t do that, it’s kind of hard to think you’re going to be able to create dialogue. Then really think about where is a good starting place? Is this something that will be accepted and embraced by the people who are in the power structure or not? And if the answer is no, then I think you start informally, where people want to come together on their own time to have these conversations. Then you figure out a good way to introduce this to the larger institution that will make it more likely that this can build out.

And you know, in an institution, if it’s really an oppressive place, and you’re thinking, I don’t want to be here unless this changes, you can do it in a way that highlights how the institution is currently closing people down. I talk in the book about “linked fate”: You find something that people in the institution care about that cannot be accomplished unless you also address these issues. You enter that way and maybe build out from there.

It’s an organizing strategy, right? It’s not just a dialogue, it’s building a constituency of people who can then influence the people who are in positions of formal power, so that you can become much more part of the organization.

(Audience) You talked about the need to work with faculty and for us to prioritize our long-term careers. Well, of course we still have to live our values and speak out, but we can’t shoulder that burden alone. What are things we can do to build the faculty ties needed to do this? There’s a perception from students that faculty, even if they don’t agree with what’s going on, that they’re not willing to stick their neck out, and I think it’s probably to some extent true. What could we do to create the environment where students support each other collaboratively?

I think there are silos going on between the faculty members [and students]. Find some informal spaces among a group of people who care about an issue, where you want to invite a few faculty to come together with students, and just have a conversation about what we do about this. So we’re interested in this issue. How can we come together and either learn together or explore together, or something like that. I think there’s a lot of openness to that.

First of all, don’t assume that apparent silence means that people are not doing things. Because they might be, but it’s just not visible.

Secondly, don’t rely only on formal channels of organizations to build these connections, build these relationships. I’d be very happy to be really concrete, to sit down with you and say: What are you thinking about? Who do you want to connect with? How can I help?

I think part of the problem here is that there aren’t these spaces generally between students and faculty. You’re either in a class, you go to office hours where you can get an important question, you’re writing a paper under someone’s supervision, or you ask for a recommendation. We need to build more spaces where faculty and students can come together as equals, come together and say, we have this shared problem. What do we do? What can you do? What can we do? I see with the student organizations, too, it becomes formalized. People don’t talk to each other. They’re in different organizations, but we’re all concerned about some of the same things. You just have to build those relationships of trust so that people can come together and work together.

Asking faculty members to sign something is most of the ways in which students have reached out to me—it is not the way to build these relationships. We could end up with that. But it’s not the way to start.

So I say, bring it on. Let’s do it. I think there are a lot of faculty members who don’t know what to do and want to do something.

This interview was conducted by Elijah Pitt ’27 and edited by Gloria Yi ’25 for length & clarity.

fields.title: A Message to the Social Justice Crowd: Less Preachiness, More Anti-Poverty
fields.content_html:
There’s not quite an anti-poverty club at CLS. The organizations that come to mind (LPE, NLG, FGP, various arms of various affinity groups) don’t fit the bill since they’re more geared toward professional networking, shared identity, or shared ideology than poverty. It’s good and fine and normal to network professionally and hang out with whatever feels like one’s crowd—this is an expensive education and a lonely city.

But I can’t stop thinking about this David Brooks line from last fall: “As the left veered toward identitarian performance art, Donald Trump jumped into the class war with both feet.” We certainly care about disadvantaged people. Rather than touching class, however, our concerns usually orbit the “In This House We Believe” yard sign criticized by historian Matt Karp:

‘Science is real,’ announces the now-ubiquitous rainbow yard sign—above ‘love is love’ and below ‘no human is illegal’—eloquently expressing the Trump-era liberal desire to reduce all politics to some combination of identity and tautology. This catechism’s failure to mention health care, jobs, or wages is not accidental.

Karp argues the lack of class issues on the sign points to a political movement “devoted to ‘a profoundly unequal but rigorously equitable form of capitalism.’” But on our campus, the relative absence of anti-poverty politics comes from less ideological, more prosaic reasons.

First, this school draws a certain kind of student and leads them to a certain kind of job. Many of us come from money and are going to more money so we don’t have a great deal of insight into poverty. Before his descent into darkness, JD Vance wrote in his memoir, Hillbilly Elegy, that being raised by his grandmother in a rough neighborhood made him an object of fascination at Yale Law School: “[F]or all of the Ivy League’s obsession with diversity, virtually everyone—black, white, Jewish, Muslim, whatever—comes from intact families who never worry about money.”1

Second, poverty is more boring than culture war. Opinions about Mahmoud Khalil SIPA ’24 come more easily than opinions about the Earned Income Tax Credit. These are extraordinary, maybe even existential times for liberal democracy so it’s natural to feel like stroking our chins and discussing the EITC phase-out might be whistling past the graveyard. But let’s not forget that the people in charge got there by pinning an affordability crisis on out-of-touch elites.

So I’d like to see the social justice set be less preachy and more interested in anti-poverty.

Be less preachy

I know nothing about Professor Susan Sturm beyond having attended her live interview with The Verdict a couple weeks ago. She seems like a nice lady and I haven’t read her book so take this criticism with a grain of salt: Professor Sturm delivered a dull sermon. Coleman Hughes CC ’20 describes how certain social justice-oriented classes at Columbia can start to feel like church: “One, it feels mean to disagree, even politely, so nobody does. And two, it’s boring to sit through if you don’t already agree with what’s being taught.”

By “being preachy” I mean delivering broad, sweeping normative claims to an audience you expect holds the same beliefs as you. Professor Sturm did this when she talked about “change,” “justice,” and “movements”—it was assumed the audience shared her understanding of what change is needed, what justice looks like, and which movements are bringing us there. Preaching can be inspiring, but more often it’s boring and priggish. How can we avoid it while advocating for things we care about? I have two suggestions.

Be self-aware

First, be self-aware. Following Trump’s victory last fall, English professor Michael Clune wrote an essay in the Chronicle of Higher Education decrying the politicization of academia titled, “We Asked For It.” He notes that people associated with “institutions that pride themselves on rejecting 70 to 95 percent of their applicants, and whose students overwhelmingly come from the upper reaches of the income spectrum, are simply not in the best position to serve as spokespeople for left-wing egalitarian values.”

I’m not asking for self-awareness in the sense of positionality statements or caveats about one’s privilege. I mean: Say things others can’t. Columbia is an elite research university—it’s not an engine for social justice in the style of Legal Aid or a public high school. If someone at Columbia preaches, “Climate change most affects the people who have done the least to cause it,” the only acceptable response is dour solidarity. There’s not much to argue or learn from, and they’re not making the most of our community. But if they say, “NEPA is stifling the green infrastructure build-out, and we need to either repeal it or find creative ways around it,” there can be productive disagreement, and we’re doing something we might not have the time or resources to do outside of the academy.

Choose effectiveness over self-expression

Second, choose effectiveness over self-expression. When Project 2025 co-author Jonathan Berry came to campus last fall, Columbia Law Students for Palestine sent out an email warning students not to attend:

While we at CLSP support free speech on campus, free speech does not mean freedom from social consequences. We’d also like to highlight for our newer students that this event is part of a pattern of antagonizing people of color and all people with uteruses on this campus. Last year, FedSoc decided to invite one of the lead attorneys on the SFFA case during Black History Month and a forced-birth judge to speak during Women’s History Month.

There’s a lot happening in this email, but fundamentally it is a preachy effort that failed to achieve its goal: Lots of people went to see Berry speak. In too many GroupMe messages and email blasts, snarkiness and score-settling come before accomplishing some end. This has been less of a problem this school year than last year, but I suspect that’s more a result of people disengaging from politics than people becoming gracious.

That’s a shame. Here are two ways of looking at politics:

Mistake theorists treat politics as science, engineering, or medicine. The State is diseased. We’re all doctors, standing around arguing over the best diagnosis and cure. Some of us have good ideas, others have bad ideas that wouldn’t help, or that would cause too many side effects.

Conflict theorists treat politics as war. Different blocs with different interests are forever fighting to determine whether the State exists to enrich the Elites or to help the People.

Some issues really are best viewed through a conflict theory lens (e.g., how your tax bill disappears when you die and give your kids appreciated assets2). But more often people’s minds can be changed. Mistake theorists who listen earnestly and treat people as individuals rather than political abstractions are usually the ones who change things. Frances Perkins GSAS ’10, probably the most effective American activist of the twentieth century, built Social Security with diplomacy rather than spitfire.

Be more interested in anti-poverty

I’m a peripheral member of the Black Law Students Association. Our leadership navigates difficult tensions with grace (is BLSA a networking service? An activist group? A social club?), and I’m constantly impressed by their work. But insofar as BLSA does activism, we’d do well to keep in mind we have different interests from most Black people:

[Black] activists are unalike the people they speak for in myriad ways. They have been, in other words, members of the Black professional-managerial class, or PMC—the late socialist critics John and Barbara Ehrenreich’s term for those whose position involves higher levels of education than the norm, occupations that are heavily involved in communicative or administrative practice, and whose technocratic skills give them advantages not just in the professional domain but in spreading their political priorities or values.3

The populist right has latched onto this gap between the activist class and normal people. Jonathan Berry’s speech was a searing critique of corporate power, presenting a brief history of how companies went from being subordinate to governments to themselves subordinating governments. That history came with talking points pulled from the DSA left: denunciations of Apple’s use of “slave labor,” criticisms of marketing, and even an explicit condemnation of that socialist-coined “professional-managerial class.” Then Berry gave a version of Patrick Deneen’s argument in How Liberalism Failed—that we need to return to a vision of freedom that’s about self-mastery instead of unlimited choice. I think Project 2025 is horrifying and suspect Berry’s “freedom as self-mastery” vision involves winding back women’s rights and LGBTQ rights, but he’s a smart dude who made these points in a way that our current student activism isn’t very responsive to.

Identity politics is great when it connects us to others but bad when it makes us self-regarding. As we advocate for the groups we care about, let’s not lose sight of the yawning class divide. From 1985 to 2025, starting Big Law salaries rose forty-five percent, from $155,000 (in 2025 dollars) to $225,000. During roughly that same period median wages across the board only rose about eight percent. Maybe that’s fine, and Rawls’s difference principle justifies it or something. But I don’t often hear this conversation, and the populist right is making political hay out of it.

We shouldn’t just tack class onto the list of causes on the “In This House We Believe” yard sign. It’s not just another consideration to add to intersectional, everything-bagel liberalism. Class is the thing. It always lurks in the background and swallows up many identity-based issues. I deal with racism, and it sucks, but there’s no way I would trade my stable upper-middle class upbringing for white privilege. For the social justice-minded among us: Let’s find more ways to engage productively with class and poverty.

Daniel Bugingo is a 2L and Lead Publisher for the Verdict.

1 JD Vance, Hillbilly Elegy 261 (2016).

2 I.R.C. § 1014

3 Fredrik deBoer, How Elites Ate the Social Justice Movement (2023).
